courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: The Study of Music
courses.description: This course explores music as a fundamental human practice, and introduces the study of music as central to broader humanistic inquiry. By engaging with styles and performance practices from various regions and historical eras, students will develop an understanding of the diverse ways in which music intersects with human experience, culture, and history. To this end, the course employs an issue-based approach. The first several class sessions deal with fundamental questions about music, such as: What is music? How do musical sounds communicate meaning? What are the relationships between musical sounds, contexts, listening habits, and human behavior? How and why do scholars study music? The remainder of the semester is devoted to particular case studies that explore music’s relationship to other realms including politics, religion, identity, and globalization. The class is structured around interactive lectures, demonstrations, discussion, and in-class group activities. No prior musical background or training is required.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:

* Become familiar with a broad range of musics and performance practices from diverse geographical locations and historical eras
* Cultivate frameworks for understanding and analyzing music as a social and cultural practice
* Develop fundamental skills in music research—how to read, listen, think, and write critically about music
* Learn to listen critically and closely, and identify musical sounds and structures through in-depth audition and discussion of musical examples
* Become familiar with diverse academic approaches to the study of music
courses.course_syllabus:
Course syllabus will vary from semester to semester, and will be distributed by the professor teaching the course at the start of the term. Topics may include:

* Introduction to the Course: Music Fundamentals
* Defining “Music”
* Musical Instruments: The Cultural Materiality of Music
* Musical Notations: Conservation, Communication, Conception
* Academic Approaches to the Study of Music: Ethnomusicology, Historical Musicology, and Music Theory
* Performance and Pedagogy
* Music, Ideology, and Politics
* Music, Identity, and Ethnicity
* Music, Migration, and Mobility
* Music, Ritual, Religion, and Spirituality
* Popular Music and Culture
* Music and Globalization
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and teaching evaluation survey will be conducted in the second to last week of the semester. Students are also welcome and encouraged to give feedback to the course teacher at any time in person or through email.
courses.required_readings:
An updated reading list will be included in the course outline distributed by the professor teaching the course. Readings may include excerpts from the following:

Nettl, Bruno. 2015. “Combining Tones: On the Concept of Music.” In *The Study of Ethnomusicology: Thirty-Three Discussions*, 19–30. University of Illinois Press.

Wade, Bonnie C. 2009. “Thinking About Instuments.” In *Thinking Musically: Experiencing Music, Expressing Culture*, 35–62. New York: Oxford University Press.

Cook, Nicholas. 2000. “Chapter 4: An Imaginary Object.” In *Music: A Very Short Introduction*, 51–73. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

Titon, Jeff. 2009. “The Music-Culture as a World of Music.” In Jeff Titon and Timothy J. Cooley, eds. *Worlds of Music: An Introduction to the Music of the World’s Peoples,* 1-32. Belmont, CA: Schirmer Cengage Learning.

Ross, Alex. 2008. *The Rest Is Noise: Listening to the Twentieth Century*. London: Fourth Estate.

Lau, Frederick. 2008. “Chapter 5: Music and Ideology.” In *Music in China: Experiencing Music, Expressing Culture*, 117–40. New York: Oxford University Press.

Lau, Frederick. 2020. “Music in China: Recalibrating Musical Heritage in a Radically Changing Society” in Bonnie Wade ed., *Global Music Culture*, Oxford University Press.

Shelemay, Kay Kaufman. 2006. “Music and Ritual.” In *Soundscapes: Exploring Music in a Changing World*, 344–79. New York: W.W. Norton.

Frith, Simon. 1996. “Toward a Popular Aesthetic.” In *Performing Rites: On the Value of Popular Music*, 269–80. New York: Oxford University Press.

Chu, Yiu-Wai, and Eve Leung. 2013. “Remapping Hong Kong Popular Music: Covers, Localisation and the Waning Hybridity of Cantopop.” *Popular Music* 32 (1): 65–78.

Beaster-Jones, Jayson. 2014. “Globalization.” Oxford Music Online.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Choral Singing I

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description: MUSC1001, 1002, 2001, 2002, 3001, 3002, 4001, 4002 form a series of 8 courses which must be taken in sequence. The first six are required, whereas the others are elective. The arts of singing in the choir. Repertoires will be chosen from the Medieval Period to the present time.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will be expected to:

- --be able to sing an independent vocal line

- --develop sight-reading and sight-singing skills

- --understand basic vocal techniques

- --appreciate choral music through interacting with other parts in singing

- --connect and understand foreign people and their culture through music

- --acquire rehearsal and performance etiquettes in choir

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: African Drumming I
courses.description: This course provides practical study of drumming selected from traditions in Africa, especially West Africa, and/or the diaspora. Techniques for playing djembe and other drum and percussion instruments are taught in conjunction with associated vocal and movement gestures.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Acquire and refine practical skills for playing djembe and other percussion instruments

• Develop techniques of ensemble playing

• Acquire an appreciation of the musics of Africa and/or its diaspora
courses.course_syllabus:
• Performance skills continuously developed in weekly rehearsals

• Appropriate movement and gesture

• Background and cultural attributes of selected repertory

• Performance/staging conventions and attitudes

• End-of-semester concert

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Chamber Music Ensemble I
courses.description: This course familiarizes students with the theoretical and practical aspects of performance in chamber music ensembles. Ensemble groups should normally consist of three or more players, and each student is allowed to join one group only. Students enrolling in this course must obtain permission from the teachers concerned, who may hold an audition.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of the course, students will be expected to demonstrate the following skills and knowledge:

1. Artistically and historically informed understanding of performance practice in the chosen repertoire

2. Practical skills in liaising with other players towards collaborative music making

3. Sensitivity in ensemble interaction

4. Professional attitude in music preparation, attendance, and punctuality

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Early Music Ensemble I
courses.description: This course provides students with opportunities to explore the vast world of early music through performance on replica period instruments. In consultation with the instructor, students select appropriate works from the repertoire, which ranges from antiquity through the early Classical era. Students prepare for an end-of-semester concert in weekly rehearsals that guide them through issues of technical proficiency, ensemble playing, stylistic accuracy, and creative expression.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Acquire skills in playing on and caring for period instruments

• Develop techniques of ensemble playing

• Develop sensitivity to issues of historical accuracy

• Formulate questions and answers about challenges in the early music repertoire

• Gain an appreciation of musical traditions that are historically distant
courses.course_syllabus:
• Correct care for and maintenance of delicate period instruments

• Sound production and issues of intonation, projection, and balance

• Historical background and cultural attributes of selected repertoire

• Possibilities for instrumentation and arrangement

• Articulation, phrasing, and rhythmic accuracy

• Challenges of notation, ornamentation, and improvisation

• Speaking and writing about early music through program notes and/or pre- and post-concert discussions

• End-of-term concert

• End Class Feedback (every lecture)

• Course Evaluation Questionnaire (mid-term)

• Course Evaluation Questionnaire (end-term)

courses.title: Jazz Ensemble I
courses.description: Jazz Ensemble provides practical study of traditional and contemporary jazz literature in a variety of idioms and styles. Students prepare for an end-of-semester concert in weekly rehearsals that enable them to develop their technical proficiency, stylistic accuracy, improvisation skills, and creative expression.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Study and perform a variety of jazz and/or popular music literature.

• Improve individual and group reading and playing skills.

• Gain insight into jazz performance styles and techniques.

• Execute idiomatic jazz rhythms, articulations, melodic phrases, and harmonic structures.

• Learn about, and engage in, the skill of improvisation.

• Develop professionalism in presenting public performances.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Tonal Music I
courses.description: A systematic introduction of tonal harmonic vocabulary that integrates part-writing, analysis, and aural training.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Basic knowledge of tonal harmonic vocabulary through part-writing, and analyses of short musical examples

from the literature.

- Fluency in practical musicianship skills, such as sight singing, harmonic and melodic dictation, as well as rhythmic

training.

- Application and integration of ear-training skills to enabling an enhanced understanding of theoretical concepts and

performance.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1

Introduction to the Course Aural Skills Placement Test

E-learning module: Review of Key, Scales, Modes, and Interval

Week 2

Foundation of Tonal Music Two-Voice Counterpoint AS Performance Presentation

Assignment #1 Due (e-learning module)

Week 3

Harmony in Musical Texture Accented and Chromatic Embellishing Tones Tutorial Session

Assignment #2 Due

Week 4

Introduction to Voice Leading Tutorial Session

Assignment #3 Due

Week 5

Tutorial Session

Assignment #4 Due

Week 6

Guest lecture by Mr. Wong Hok Yueng Tonic and Dominant as Tonal Pillars Introduction to V7

Week 7

Chung Yueng Festival Holiday

Week 8

Group and individual AS Test and Performance Presentation

Week 9

Contrapuntal Expansions: Six-Three Chords Contrapuntal Expansions: V7, viio7 & their inversions Tutorial Session

Assignment #5 Due

Week 10

The Pre-Dominant Function: IV, ii Contrapuntal Expansions: Six-Four Chord & IV Tutorial Session

Assignment #6 Due

Week 11

Extending the Pre-Dominant The Submediant The Mediant

Assignment #7 Due

Week 12

Final Exam Review Tutorial Session

Assignment #8 Due

Week 13

Aural and written test

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Fundamentals of Tonal Music II
courses.description: A continuation of the concepts covered in MUSC1212.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC1212
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Comprehensive knowledge of tonal harmonic vocabulary through part-writing, and analyses of musical examples

from the literature.

- Proficiency in practical musicianship skills, such as sight singing, harmonic and melodic dictation, as well as rhythmic

training.

- Application and integration of ear-training skills to enabling an enhanced understanding of theoretical concepts and

performance.
courses.course_syllabus:
W1 Course Introduction Review of Cadences, T-P-D-T, non-harmonic tones and six-four chords

W2 Review of Voice-leading Conventions \*Aural Sessions (AS) Begins

W3 Seventh Chords and Diatonic Sequence

W4 Diatonic Sequence II

W5 No Class - Lunar New Year

W6 Aural Test

W7 Applied Chords I

W8 Applied Chords II

W9 The Phrygian II (Neapolitan) Augmented Sixth Chords (I) Analysis and Voice-leading

W10 Augmented Sixth Chords (II) Application

W11 Diatonic Modulation (I) Analysis

W12 Diatonic Modulation (II) Application

W13 No Class - Reading Week

W14 Course Review and Harmonization Discussion

W15 Aural Project Session

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Choral Singing III

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description: MUSC1001, 1002, 2001, 2002, 3001, 3002, 4001, 4002 form a series of 8 courses which must be taken in sequence. The first six are required, whereas the others are elective. The arts of singing in the choir. Repertoires will be chosen from the Medieval Period to the present time.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will be expected to:

- --be able to sing an independent vocal line

- --develop sight-reading and sight-singing skills

- --understand basic vocal techniques

- --appreciate choral music through interacting with other parts in singing

- --connect and understand foreign people and their culture through music

- --acquire rehearsal and performance etiquettes in choir

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: African Drumming III
courses.description: This course provides practical study of drumming selected from traditions in Africa, especially West Africa, and/or the diaspora. Techniques for playing djembe and other drum and percussion instruments are taught in conjunction with associated vocal and movement gestures.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Acquire and refine practical skills for playing djembe and other percussion instruments

• Develop techniques of ensemble playing

• Acquire an appreciation of the musics of Africa and/or its diaspora
courses.course_syllabus:
• Performance skills continuously developed in weekly rehearsals

• Appropriate movement and gesture

• Background and cultural attributes of selected repertory

• Performance/staging conventions and attitudes

• End-of-semester concert

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Chamber Music Ensemble III
courses.description: This course familiarizes students with the theoretical and practical aspects of performance in chamber music ensembles. Ensemble groups should normally consist of three or more players, and each student is allowed to join one group only. Students enrolling in this course must obtain permission from the teachers concerned, who may hold an audition.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of the course, students will be expected to demonstrate the following skills and knowledge:

1. Artistically and historically informed understanding of performance practice in the chosen repertoire

2. Practical skills in liaising with other players towards collaborative music making

3. Sensitivity in ensemble interaction

4. Professional attitude in music preparation, attendance, and punctuality

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Early Music Ensemble III
courses.description: This course provides students with opportunities to explore the vast world of early music through performance on replica period instruments. In consultation with the instructor, students select appropriate works from the repertoire, which ranges from antiquity through the early Classical era. Students prepare for an end-of-semester concert in weekly rehearsals that guide them through issues of technical proficiency, ensemble playing, stylistic accuracy, and creative expression.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Acquire skills in playing on and caring for period instruments

• Develop techniques of ensemble playing

• Develop sensitivity to issues of historical accuracy

• Formulate questions and answers about challenges in the early music repertoire

• Gain an appreciation of musical traditions that are historically distant
courses.course_syllabus:
• Correct care for and maintenance of delicate period instruments

• Sound production and issues of intonation, projection, and balance

• Historical background and cultural attributes of selected repertoire

• Possibilities for instrumentation and arrangement

• Articulation, phrasing, and rhythmic accuracy

• Challenges of notation, ornamentation, and improvisation

• Speaking and writing about early music through program notes and/or pre- and post-concert discussions

• End-of-term concert

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Jazz Ensemble III
courses.description: Jazz Ensemble provides practical study of traditional and contemporary jazz literature in a variety of idioms and styles. Students prepare for an end-of-semester concert in weekly rehearsals that enable them to develop their technical proficiency, stylistic accuracy, improvisation skills, and creative expression.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Study and perform a variety of jazz and/or popular music literature.

• Improve individual and group reading and playing skills.

• Gain insight into jazz performance styles and techniques.

• Execute idiomatic jazz rhythms, articulations, melodic phrases, and harmonic structures.

• Learn about, and engage in, the skill of improvisation.

• Develop professionalism in presenting public performances.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Performance skills continuously developed in weekly rehearsals

• Appropriate movement and performance gesture

• Background and cultural attributes of selected repertory

• Performance/staging conventions and attitudes

• End-of-semester concert

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Materials and Structures of Music
courses.description: The study of tonal harmonic practice in Western music, with an emphasis on the operating principles behind the structuring of materials.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC1222 or by consent of the instructor
courses.learning_outcomes:
The successful student should demonstrate:

- a thorough knowledge of common-practice harmony,

- an understanding of the tonal harmonic language through listening as well as through analysis of music scores, and

- an awareness of the ways common-practice materials are structured through writing music in the styles concerned.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Harmonic Practice
courses.description: This is a more in-depth study of the harmonic techniques used by western composers in the classical and romantic period, with special emphasis on developing students’ ability to analyze and write in the various important harmonic styles concerned.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC2252 OR by consent of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The successful student should demonstrate:

- a thorough knowledge of the harmonic techniques used by western composers in the classical and romantic period;
- an appreciation for traditional values through the creative process of writing music in various 18th and 19th century styles, and

- an understanding of the important compositional concepts related to freedom and boundaries, simplicity and complexity, tension and relaxation, unity and contrasts etc. typical of the styles concerned.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music Information Technology
courses.description: This course introduces the usage and the application of the most up-to-date computer and electronic technology in the field of music. Emphasis will be placed on the theory and practice of computer music software and knowledge of various recording media.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic Sound Theory 1.1 Nature of sound and vibration 1.2 Knowledge and application of audio equipment

2. Musical Instrument Digital Interface (MIDI) 2.1 Introduction to MIDI and its history 2.2 MIDI application

3. Recording 3.1 Theory of Analog and digital recording 3.2 Theory of different type of microphone 3.3 Technique of field recording 3.4 Microphone placement 3.5 Music Recording 3.6 Introduction to HardDisk Recording system and audio editing (Case study: ProTools)

4. Computer Scoring and Sequencing 4.1 Introduction to the Notation software (Case study: Finale ) 4.2 Introduction to the Sequencing software (Case study: Digital Performer)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation questionnaires will be distributed during the course, one at week 5 or 6, and the other at the end of the course. Students can also have personal feedback to the instructor directly through email or in-person appointments.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Aural Practice and Perception I
courses.description: This course provides training sessions and conveys methodologies of practical aural skills comprehending aspects of melody, harmony and rhythm as well as topics of understanding music appearance and aural analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: Grade B or above in MUSC1222 or permission by the instructor
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students will have:
1. Enhanced practical aural skills through recognition and notation
2. Acquired appropriate dexterity in music listening and reading
3. The ability to correlate aural ability with theoretical knowledge and other music activities
4. Developed analytical perception and critical mind while confronting different musical interpretations
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Melodic perception and notation
- Sight singing
- Memorize and sing in solfege
- Notate in different clefs including tenor and alto clefs
> Focus on single-line melody

2. Harmonic perception and notation
- Chord quality and chord progression recognition
- Modulation recognition
> Encompassing functional harmony until early Romantic period

3. Rhythmic perception and notation
- Sight performance of rhythm
- Memorize and perform (sing, clap, etc.)
- Notate
> Regular meters, simple and compound meters
> Dotted figures and syncopation
> Subdivisions and triplets

4. General perception and aural analysis
- Error detections
> Instrumental intonation and timbres
> Texture
> Basic form and structure

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Aural Practice and Perception II
courses.description: This course provides training sessions and conveys methodologies of practical aural skills comprehending aspects of melody, harmony and rhythm as well as topics of understanding music appearance and aural analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MUSC2511 or permission by the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students will have:
1. Enhanced practical aural skills through recognition and notation
2. Acquired appropriate dexterity in music listening and reading
3. The ability to correlate aural ability with theoretical knowledge and other music activities
4. Developed analytical perception and critical mind while confronting different musical interpretations
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Melodic perception and notation
- Sight singing
- Memorize and sing in solfege
- Notate in different clefs including tenor and alto clefs
> With counterpoint, two lines or more
> Score reading and notation with transposing instrument
> Simple atonal melody

2. Harmonic perception and notation
- Chord quality and chord progression recognition
- Modulation recognition
> Functional harmony and chromaticism in late Romantic Period
> Post-tonal harmonic language in early Twentieth Century music

3. Rhythmic perception and notation
- Sight performance of rhythm
- Memorize and perform (sing, clap, etc.)
- Notate
> More complex figures, smaller divisions and duplets
> Irregular meters
> Polyrhythms

4. General perception and aural analysis
- Error detections
> Instrumental intonation and timbres
>Texture
> Basic form and structure
> Consolidation of work done in Aural Practice and Perception I

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: An Introduction to Arts Management
courses.description: This course aims to introduce students to key aspects and concepts of arts management as well as examine how musicians can make useful application of them. In addition to learning how to design and execute a music/arts project, students will undertake a critical study of the arts/cultural ecology in Hong Kong which affects the management of all local arts institutions. These knowledge and insights would enhance students’ abilities to promote and disseminate music/arts to the community.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Gain an overview of the fundamental concepts and skills in arts management & promotion
* Understand the key components and key players in the local arts/cultural ecology and how they influence the production, distribution and engagement of the arts in Hong Kong
* Acquire the skill to design and plan an arts event which has potential to realize its pre-determined objectives
* Learn from best practices and innovations of selected arts groups
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will introduce students to key concepts of arts management and promotion, including but not limited to planning, programming, marketing, audience development, fundraising, financial & human resources management. Case studies illustrating best practices and innovations of selected local and overseas arts groups will be discussed.

Main components and major players in the local arts ecology, from creation, production, distribution, marketing to consumption, will be examined This will enable students to understand the context within which local music /arts institutions (including festivals) operate.

Special emphasis will be given to the planning and execution of music /arts programmes. In addition to learning theories and concepts of project management, students will apply these in the design and planning of arts projects which achieve specific objectives.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music in World Cultures
courses.description: A study of several selected musical cultures from around the world, including Asia, Africa, Europe, Oceania, and the Americas. Emphasis is placed on listening to and understanding musical styles within native contexts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC2552 or permission by the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Gain specific musical knowledge about several non-Western and non-Chinese musical traditions

- Understand the roles music and musical performance play in the functioning of selected world societies and cultures

- Develop critical listening skills to foster appreciation and facilitate cross-cultural evaluation and analysis

- Learn to analyze musical and cultural systems cross-culturally and on their own terms
courses.course_syllabus:
Unit I Introduction: Global Perceptions

Conceptualizing World Musics and World Cultures

Listening to World Musics and World Cultures

Unit II Music-Cultures of the Western Continents

Music of “The West” as World Music ₡ Flamenco (Spain), Bagpiping (Scotland) ∮ Traditional music (Ireland)

Musics of “Orthodox/Slavic” Eurasia ₡ Orthodox chant (Greece), Szájbögö (Roma, Hungary), Folk music (Bulgaria) ∮ Folk music (Russia)

Soundworlds of Sub-Saharan Africa ₡ Atsia (Ewe, Ghana), Mabo (BaAka, Central African Republic) ∮ Jali stylings (Mande of Senegal, The Gambia, and Mali)

Class Postponed (Meeting TBD)

Indigenous Musics of the Americas ₡ Sikuri (Quechua/Aymara), Grass Dance (Sioux), Quiver Dance (Iroquois) ∮ Ceremonial musics (Navajo/Diné)

Musics of Latin America ₡ Salsa (Cuba), Son jarocho (Mexico) ∮ Afro-Brazilian musics (Brazil)

Unit III Music-Cultures of the East

Middle Eastern Musical Sensibilities ₡ Dastgah (Iran), Jewish cantillation (Israel) ∮ Folk dance forms (Egypt)

Musics of the Indic World ₡ Bhangra (Punjab/UK/US), Qawwali (Pakistan) ∮ Karnataka sangeeta (India)

Musics of East Asia ₡ Buddhist ritual music (Tibet), P’ansori (South Korea) ∮ Sankyoku (Japan)

Soundworlds of Southeast Asia ₡ Folk gong ensemble music (Vietnam), Piphat (Thailand) ∮ Gamelan beleganjur (Bali, Indonesia)

Musics of Oceania ₡ Wangga (Australia), Badra (Papua New Guinea), Bino (Kiribati) ∮ Traditional and popular musics (Hawai’i, USA)

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music Therapy
courses.description: This course introduces students to two well-known approaches to music therapy (Behavioural Music Therapy and Psychodynamic Music Therapy) and explores the application of these approaches in education, rehabilitation, psychotherapy and personal development. The learning activities include lecture, group discussion, video watching, listening to music, reading and role-play. Students will be required to play a musical instrument in the role-play as demonstration and assessment. Therefore, students must have attained at least Grade 5 in one musical instrument (excluding voice) in the examination of the Associated Board of the Royal Schools of Music, or equivalent level for a Chinese musical instrument.
courses.learning_outcomes:
 Recognize and differentiate the principle of the Behavioural Music Therapy (BMT) and Psychodynamic Music Therapy (PMT),

 Show a basic understanding of how music therapy can applied to education and rehabilitation settings, and facilitate emotional expression and enhance psychological well-being,

 Design goal-oriented musical activities catering for the clients’ levels and needs,

 Demonstrate basic activity leading skills learnt in lecture such as: the therapeutic application of lyric appreciation, singing, the integration of creative arts and music therapy,

 Plan and conduct a music session with populations in education and rehabilitation settings,

 Apply the aforementioned skills in practical music session in actual settings.
courses.course_syllabus:
No./Topic/Contents/fundamental concepts

1. Introduction to Music Therapy: This lesson presents a broad overview of music therapy.

2. Clients in Music Therapy: This lesson establishes a practical guide to common music therapy clienteles in music therapy sessions.

3. Behavioural Music Therapy I: This lesson explains the concept, principle and techniques in behavioural music therapy.

4. Behavioural Music Therapy II: This lesson introduces the structured musical activities for speech and language training.

5. Behavioural Music Therapy III: This lesson introduces structured musical activities for motor skills training.

6. Behavioural Music Therapy IV: This lesson introduces structured musical activities for establishing social skills.

7. Project Demonstration: This lesson lets students present their musical activity projects.

8. Psychodynamic Music Therapy (PMT): This lesson introduces the basic concept and principle of psychodynamic music therapy.

9. Psychodynamic Music Therapy Technique I: This lesson introduces clinical improvisation techniques: Dialogue and Reframing.

10. Psychodynamic Music Therapy Technique II : This lesson introduces more clinical improvisation techniques: Containment and group PMT.

11. Therapeutic Relationship and Symbolic Play: This lesson introduces about building client-therapist relationship and symbolic meaning in PMT.

12. Research and Professional Study in Music Therapy and Summary: This lesson introduces both quantitative and qualitative researches in music therapy with different examples, and different overseas programmes in music therapy, and a review of the whole module.

13. Written Examination

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music, Culture and Society
courses.description: Focusing on ethnographic perspective of music studies, the course explores the relationship between music, culture and society. Musical examples will be drawn from Western, Chinese, and other societies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through this course, students will:

- Acquire an analytic vocabulary that will enable appreciation of a variety of musics from different socio-cultural contexts

- Learn about ethnomusicological and ethnographic methods of studying music

- Develop critical thinking, listening, and writing skills

- Gain an understanding of how music works in relation to its culture and society

- Achieve a deeper understanding of how music works within their own society

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Foundations of Chinese Music
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce basic historical concepts and genres of Chinese music to students. It provides a comprehensive theoretical framework and understanding of existing genres in Chinese music, and it also tries to stress the relevance to history and the modern world. This will be a foundation for further studies of Chinese music.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through this course, students will:

- Gain a broad view of Chinese music, including its history, important genres, and standard repertoires

- Have a general understanding of the differences and similarities of Chinese and Western cultures with reference to

performance practice and aesthetics

- Further understand how music is related to culture, politics and society

Develop their broad perspective to world music with Chinese music as part of it, pull them out of the narrow obsession

of the “mainstreams” of modern commercial world

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: History of Western Music I
courses.description: Through critical listening and reading assignments, this course introduces students to the history of Western music from antiquity until the eighteenth century. Students explore issues of musical style and analysis, as well as the cultural significance of music in Western society. Emphasis is placed on understanding music in its historical contexts, and developing skills for interpreting medieval and early modern repertoires. The successful completion of MUSC2872 will provide students with a foundation for other classes in Western music history.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will be able to:

•Generalize about significant genres, theories, performance practices, and musical conventions of the period in question.

•Compare specific examples of the genres studied.

•Employ historically informed listening in the critical assessment of performances.

•Analyze and transcribe a variety of medieval and early modern musical notations.
courses.course_syllabus:
Dates/ Lectures/Reading + Listening

THE MEDIEVAL ERA

4 September: Plainchant and Secular Monophony (Bonds, Chapter 1)

11 September: Polyphony to 1300 (Bonds, Chapter 2)

18 September: Music in the 14th Century (Bonds, Chapter 3)

25 September: Unit Test 1

2 October No Class – Holiday

THE RENAISSANCE

9 October: The Emergence of Renaissance Style (Bonds, Chapter 4)

16 October: The Genres of Renaissance Music, 1420–1520 (Bonds, Chapter 5)

23 October: Music in the 16th Century (Bonds, Chapter 6)

30 October Unit Test 2

6 November Performances/Presentations

THE BAROQUE ERA

13 November: Vocal Music, 1600–1700 (Bonds, Chapter 8)

20 November: Instrumental Music, 1600–1700 (Bonds, Chapter 9)

27 November: Vocal and Instrumental Music, 1700–1750 (Bonds, Chapter 10)

Date TBA: Unit Test 3
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Required Feedback for Evaluation

•Mid-term Evaluations: Students will be asked to provide preliminary feedback on course organization, clarity of lectures, workload, etc.

•Discussion Forum on WebCT: Students may initiate topics for discussion themselves, or respond to the comments or questions posted by other students or the instructor.

•Course Teaching Evaluations: Students will be asked to provide feedback for the entire term.
courses.required_readings: Mark Evan Bonds, A History of Music in Western Culture, Fourth Edition.
courses.recommended_readings:
Atlas, Allan W. Renaissance Music: Music in Western Europe, 1400-1600. New York: Norton, 1998.

Hanning, Barbara Russano. Concise History of Western Music. 4th ed. New York: Norton, 2010.

Hoppin, Richard H. Medieval Music. New York: Norton, 1978.

Norton Anthology of Western Music:. 6th ed. Ed. J. Peter Burkholder and Claude V. Palisca. Vol. 1, Ancient to Baroque. New York: Norton, 2010.

Norton Recorded Anthology of Western Music. Concise ed. New York: Norton, 2006.

Opera: A History in Documents. Ed. Piero Weiss. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002.

Strunk’s Source Readings in Music History. Rev ed. Ed. Leo Treitler. New York: Norton, 1998.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: History of Western Music II
courses.description: Through critical listening and reading assignments, this course introduces students to the history of Western music from the eighteenth century to the present. Students explore issues of musical style and analysis, as well as the cultural significance of music in Western society. Emphasis is placed on understanding music in its historical contexts, and developing skills for interpreting Classical, Romantic, Modern and Postmodern repertoires. The successful completion of MUSC2882 will provide students with a foundation for other classes in Western music history designed to explore individual topics in depth.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will be able to:

•Generalize about significant genres, theories, performance practices, and musical conventions of the period in question.

•Compare specific examples of the genres studied.

•Employ historically informed listening in the critical assessment of performances.
courses.course_syllabus:
Date/Lectures and Tutorials/Reading/Listening

THE CLASSICAL ERA

11 January: Instrumental Music in the Classical Era (Bonds, Chapter 11)

18 January: Instrumental Music in the Classical Era (Bonds, Chapter 12)

25 January: Vocal Music in the Classical Era (Bonds, Chapter 13)

1 February: UNIT TEST 1

THE 19TH CENTURY

8 February: The Age of the Tone Poet; Orchestral Music 1800-1850 (Bonds, Chapters 14 and 15)

22 February: Piano Music, Chamber Music, Song (Bonds, Chapter 16)

1 March: Dramatic Music and Orchestral Music, 1850-1900 (Bonds, Chapters 17 and 18)

8 March: UNIT TEST 2

15 March: PERFORMANCES

THE 20TH CENTURY

22 March: The Growth of Pluralism; The Search for New Sounds, 1890-1945 (Bonds, Chapters 19 and 20)

29 March: NO CLASS: READING WEEK

5 April: NO CLASS: HOLIDAY

12 April: Beyond Tonality; The Tonal Tradition (Bonds, Chapters 21 and 22)

19 April: New Currents after 1945 (Bonds, Chapter 23)

Date TBA: UNIT TEST 3

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Choral Singing V

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description: MUSC1001, 1002, 2001, 2002, 3001, 3002, 4001, 4002 form a series of 8 courses which must be taken in sequence. The first six are required, whereas the others are elective. The arts of singing in the choir. Repertoires will be chosen from the Medieval Period to the present time.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will be expected to:

- --be able to sing an independent vocal line

- --develop sight-reading and sight-singing skills

- --understand basic vocal techniques

- --appreciate choral music through interacting with other parts in singing

- --connect and understand foreign people and their culture through music

- --acquire rehearsal and performance etiquettes in choir

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: African Drumming V
courses.description: This course provides practical study of drumming selected from traditions in Africa, especially West Africa, and/or the diaspora. Techniques for playing djembe and other drum and percussion instruments are taught in conjunction with associated vocal and movement gestures.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Acquire and refine practical skills for playing djembe and other percussion instruments

• Develop techniques of ensemble playing

• Acquire an appreciation of the musics of Africa and/or its diaspora
courses.course_syllabus:
• Performance skills continuously developed in weekly rehearsals

• Appropriate movement and gesture

• Background and cultural attributes of selected repertory

• Performance/staging conventions and attitudes

• End-of-semester concert

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Chamber Music Ensemble V
courses.description: This course familiarizes students with the theoretical and practical aspects of performance in chamber music ensembles. Ensemble groups should normally consist of three or more players, and each student is allowed to join one group only. Students enrolling in this course must obtain permission from the teachers concerned, who may hold an audition.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of the course, students will be expected to demonstrate the following skills and knowledge:

1. Artistically and historically informed understanding of performance practice in the chosen repertoire

2. Practical skills in liaising with other players towards collaborative music making

3. Sensitivity in ensemble interaction

4. Professional attitude in music preparation, attendance, and punctuality

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Early Music Ensemble V
courses.description: This course provides students with opportunities to explore the vast world of early music through performance on replica period instruments. In consultation with the instructor, students select appropriate works from the repertoire, which ranges from antiquity through the early Classical era. Students prepare for an end-of-semester concert in weekly rehearsals that guide them through issues of technical proficiency, ensemble playing, stylistic accuracy, and creative expression.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Acquire skills in playing on and caring for period instruments

• Develop techniques of ensemble playing

• Develop sensitivity to issues of historical accuracy

• Formulate questions and answers about challenges in the early music repertoire

• Gain an appreciation of musical traditions that are historically distant
courses.course_syllabus:
• Correct care for and maintenance of delicate period instruments

• Sound production and issues of intonation, projection, and balance

• Historical background and cultural attributes of selected repertoire

• Possibilities for instrumentation and arrangement

• Articulation, phrasing, and rhythmic accuracy

• Challenges of notation, ornamentation, and improvisation

• Speaking and writing about early music through program notes and/or pre- and post-concert discussions

• End-of-term concert

courses.title: Jazz Ensemble V
courses.description: Jazz Ensemble provides practical study of traditional and contemporary jazz literature in a variety of idioms and styles. Students prepare for an end-of-semester concert in weekly rehearsals that enable them to develop their technical proficiency, stylistic accuracy, improvisation skills, and creative expression.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Study and perform a variety of jazz and/or popular music literature.

• Improve individual and group reading and playing skills.

• Gain insight into jazz performance styles and techniques.

• Execute idiomatic jazz rhythms, articulations, melodic phrases, and harmonic structures.

• Learn about, and engage in, the skill of improvisation.

• Develop professionalism in presenting public performances.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: History of Western Music: Special Topic I
courses.description: Specialized historical or genre studies exploring aspects of music creation, analysis, or performance of Western music. A substantial oral presentation and/or research paper will be required during each term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MUSC2813 and 2823 (for 3-year cohort) OR MUSC2872 and 2882 (for 4-year cohort) OR by consent of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will have:

• An enhanced understanding of critical issues concerning the period and music

• Gained experience in thinking critical about music history and culture

• Gained proficiency in expressing their views about music both verbally and in writing

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Counterpoint (Tonal and Modern)
courses.description: The study of contrapuntal techniques used between 1700 and the present, including the writing of fugue.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC2262 or permission by the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes: As with any course in Music Theory, the ultimate goal is to help students become a better musician.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 Introduction to the Course
Week 2 Figured bass and harmony review Single Melodic Line
Week 3 Simple Counterpoint (1:1)
Week 4 Two-Voice Counterpoint (1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1) Written Assignment #1 Due
Week 5 No Class—Lunar New Year Holiday
Week 6 Tutorial with TAs
Week 7 Writing of Short Two-Voice Pieces (dance form)
Week 8 Canon and Invertible Counterpoint Written Assignment #2 Due
Week 9 Two-part Inventions
Week 10 Three-Voice Counterpoint and the Three-Part Inventions (trio sonatas) Written Assignment #3 Due
Week 11 Fugue I
Week 12 Fugue II Written Assignment #4 Due
Week 13 No Class—Reading Week
Week 14 Fugue III
Week 15 Fugue IV

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Orchestral Techniques
courses.description: A practical guide to the art of orchestration.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC2262 or permission by the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes: As with any course in Music Theory, the ultimate goal is to help students become a better musician.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 Introduction to the Course General Concepts of Orchestration

Week 2 Arrange and transcribe orchestral music for the piano

Week 3 Bowed String Instruments (Violin, Viola, Cello, Double Bass) Natural and Artificial Harmonics Written Assignment No. 1 Due

Week 4 Scoring for Strings Contemporary String Techniques Written Assignment No. 2 Due

Week 5 Woodwind Instruments (Piccolo, Flute, Oboe, English Horn, Clarinet, Bass Clarinet, Bassoon, Contrabassoon) Week 6 Scoring for Woodwinds Contemporary Woodwind Techniques

Week 7 No class (Public Holiday)—Chung Yeung Festival

Week 8 Brass Instruments (Trumpet, Trombone, French Horn, Tuba, Euphonium) Written Assignment No. 3 Due

Week 9 Scoring for Brass Contemporary Brass Techniques

Week 10 Writing for the Harp Percussion Instruments

Week 11 Scoring for full orchestra (I)

Week 12 Scoring for full orchestra (II)

Week 13 \*Various events with Ensemble Mise-en (compulsory)

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Scoring for Film and Television
courses.description: This course introduces the technique of scoring for motion pictures and television, including music for commercials, dramatic film, animated film, documentaries and television episodes. Emphasis is placed on developing technical skills and encouraging student creativity.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC2333 or permission by the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- To provide the students techniques of writing music for various kind of film

- To provide the students technical requirement and the industry procedure of writing film music

- To enable the students to communicate with film makers and directors
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Function of music in the sound film

2. FUNCTIONAL MUSIC

(i) Music and action

(ii) Scenic and place music

(iii) Period and pageant Music

(iv) Music for dramatic tension

(v) Comedy music

(vi) Music for human emotion

(vii) Music in animated and specialized films

3. Thematic and motivic development of film music

4. The tradition of symphonic film Score and film music renaissance

5. The rebirth of leitmotif

6. Synchronizing music to picture

7. Music for documentary

8. Music for commercials
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation questionnaires will be distributed during the course, one at week 5 or 6, and the other at the end of the course. Students can also have personal feedback to the instructor directly through email or in-person appointments.
courses.required_readings: There are no designated textbooks for this course though students are strongly recommended to own at least one book for reference.
courses.recommended_readings:
Prendergast, Roy M. Film Music: A Neglected Art. New York : W.W. Norton & Company, Inc., 1977.

Manvell, Roger, John Huntley. The Technique of Film music. New York: Focal Press Inc, 1980.

Kalinak, Kathryn. Settling the score. Wisconsin: The University of Wisconsin Press, 1992.

Kompanek, Sonny. From Score to Screen The New Film Scoring Process. New York: Schirmer Trade Book, 2004.

Adorno, Theodor, Hanns Eisler. Composing for the Films. London: The Athlone Press, 1994.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Electronic Music
courses.description: History and repertoire of electronic music, basic principles of electronic music and sound theory, introduction to MIDI and its applications, notation software, digital recording and editing. Emphasis will be placed on the practical nature of the processes with students involved in the course assignments. Knowledge in music information technology is preferred. There will be an interview before the start of an academic year.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

1. 1 History of Electronic music

1. 2 Composers and repertoire of electronic music

2. Sound synthesis

2. 1 Introduction to sound synthesis

2. 2 Theory of Analog Synthesizer (Case Study: Synthi and Theremin)

2. 3 Amplifier, Filter, LFO and Envelope

2. 4 Introduction to FM and sample playback synthesis (Case Study:

Yamaha DX 7 and Korg Z1)

2. 5 Performance Control

2. 6 Alternative Controller

3. Advance knowledge of Musical Instrument Digital Interface (MIDI)

3. 1 Advanced MIDI application

3. 2 MIDI show control

4. Digital Recording and Digital multi-track Recording

4. 1 Theory of Digital recording and Hard disk recording

4. 2 Multi-track recording

4. 3 Digital sound editing

4. 4 Digital process of sound (DSP)

5. Sampling

5. 1 Sampler Vs Sound synthesizer

5. 2 Set up and recording

5. 3 sample edit and programming (Case study: Akai S6000)

6. Signal Processing

6. 1 Theory of Signal process

6. 2 Usage of signal processor

8. Computer Software Application

8. 1 Introduction to Music programming software (Case study: MAX/MSP)

8. 2 Introduction to CSound
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation questionnaires will be distributed during the course, one at week 5 or 6, and the other at the end of the course. Students can also have personal feedback to the instructor directly through email or in-person appointments.

courses.description: Analytical studies of formal archetypes and musical works from the Western tonal tradition. Emphasis will be placed on the harmonic principles underlying music in various genres and styles from the common practice period and how these may serve expressive goals.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Post-tonal Music Analysis
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC3432. A critical survey and review of canonical post-tonal theories through the analyses of selected works from the late nineteenth through the first half of the twentieth century, with emphasis on the music of Bartók, Debussy, Schoenberg, Stravinsky, and Webern.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC3432 or permission by the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Acquired comprehensive knowledge of posttonal theories

- Acquired posttonal analytical skills

- Gained experience in reading intellectually challenging texts

- Gained experience in writing critiques and argumentative essays

courses.course_syllabus:
1-4

The Rite of Spring

 Taruskin, Richard. Chapter 12 ‘The Great Fusion (The Rite of Spring)’ in Stravinsky and the Russian Traditions: a Biography of the Works Through Mavra. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1996.

 Code, David. “The Synthesis of Rhythms: Form, Ideology, and the ‘Augurs of Spring’”. The Journal of Musicology, Vol. 24, No. 1 (2007), pp. 112–166.

 Messiaen, Olivier. ‘Analyse du « Sacre du Printernps » de Strawinsky’ in Chapitre III ‘Personnages rythmiques’ in Traité de rythme, de couleur et d’ornithologie, tome II (Paris: Alphonse Leduc, 1995).

 Boulez, “Strawinsky demeure”, in Musique russe, ed. Pierre Souvtchinsky (Paris: Presses Universitaires de France, 1953), vol. 1, pp. 151−24; trans. Stephen Walsh as ‘Stravinsky Remains’, in Stocktakings from the Apprenticeship, pp. 55−110.

5-7

Petrushka

 Taruskin, Richard. Chapter 10 ‘Punch into Pierrot (Petrushka)’ in Stravinsky and the Russian Traditions: a Biography of the Works Through Mavra. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1996.

 van den Toorn, Pieter C. Chapter 3 ‘Stravinsky Re-barred’ and Chapter 4 ‘Rhythmic Structure’ in Stravinsky and The Rite of Spring: the Beginnings of a Musical Language. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1987.

 van den Toorn, Pieter C., and John McGinness. Chapter 1 ‘Meter and metrical displacement in Stravinsky’ in Stravinsky and the Russian Period: Sound and Legacy of a Musical Idiom. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 2012.

8-10

Firebird

 Taruskin, Richard. Chapter 9 ‘Myths for Export (Firebird)’ in Stravinsky and the Russian Traditions: a Biography of the Works Through Mavra. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1996.

11

Individual supervision

12

courses.description: Introduction and exploration of advanced music-analytical methodologies and/or theoretical issues in relation to particular composers, styles or repertoires.
courses.course_syllabus:

• Beach, Ch. 2 (cont.)

• Various short examples

• Assignment 3

• Beach, Ch. 3 and 5

• Assignment 4

• Schubert, String Quartet in A minor, D. 804, III, Menuetto section

• Assignment 5

• Assignment 8

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Analysis and Performance
courses.description: This course offers upper undergraduates the opportunity to explore the interactions between analysis and performance in tonal music. Factors that affect interpretative decisions such as the choice of editions, stylistic competency, historical performance practice, generic and formal expectations, rhythmic and metrical awareness, harmonic sensitivity and structural understanding will be addressed in turn. Concepts will be introduced primarily by way of scores and recordings, and readings will also be assigned where appropriate. Students should be prepared to engage in music making (singing and/or playing). This is a recommended course for performance stream students and an elective for others.
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Introductory lecture: Analytical choices in performance
2 Structural Understanding in performances:
• formal and expressive articulation;
• “architectural” vs “real-time” perceptions of musical structure
• “performer’s analysis” vs “theorist’s analysis”
• drastic vs gnostic
3 The Work Concept
• Issues of ontology, intentionality, authenticity, and the limits of interpretation

4 What scores tell us
• Types of notational systems
• Western art music notation: capabilities and limits
• Facsimile, historical, interpretive and critical editions
• The Urtext myth

5 Agency and the act of performance
• parallel developments in
instrumental construction, compositional style, and aesthetic values
• idiomatic and nonidiomatic writing
• rhetorical and expressive intentions
originality vs authenticity

6 Workshop I: Knowing your instrument
7 Historical keyboard performance practice: guest lecture demonstration by Constanze Lee
8 Ornamentation, Improvisation, Cadenzas
• Dual demands of virtuosity and musical invention
• Historical and stylistic considerations
• role of analysis
9 Workshop II: recording or edition critique
10 Traditional Chinese music
(guest lecture demonstration by Chan Pik Sum and Chan Chi Chun)

11 Performance practices in contemporary art music
No class – reading week
12 Workshop III: analyzing your own performance
13 Workshop III (cont.)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation questionnaires will be distributed twice during the course, one at mid term and the other at the end of the course. Students are also strongly encouraged to express informal feedback to the professor and TA directly via email or in-person appointments.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Vocal/Instrumental Pedagogy
courses.description: In this course, students explore historical and current approaches to teaching music. Through a combination of independent study and group work, each student will gain a broad knowledge of the approaches to musical instruction and thorough knowledge of the methods of teaching his or her primary instrument. Topics may include the teaching of voice, strings, winds, and percussion.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students will have:

• A sound knowledge of the recent literature on teaching methods for their instrument and of the many teaching resources available

• Broadened their understanding of teaching strategies and methods

• Gained a good, general knowledge of the history the pedagogy for their instrument

• Developed the skills and practice of continuously improving their teaching
courses.course_syllabus:
Each class will be devoted to both discussion of theoretical issues and student-led introductions to the pedagogical methods of specific instruments. Instrumental and vocal methods may include: traditional Chinese instruments, guitar, harp, strings, brass, woodwinds, percussion, and voice

Readings will explore

• Research methods and sources

• Processes in instrumental learning

• Ensemble instruction

• Teaching children and adolescents

• Teaching in schools

• Choral music

• Teaching adults

• Motivation and achievement

• Exam preparation

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music Performer’s Issues
courses.description: What does it take for performers to deliver a secure performance on stage? Why can’t one deliver a successful performance despite endless hours of practice? Do performers still want to perform live when everybody has free access to world-class concerts online? This course examines challenges faced by performers and provides practical advices on issues including practice strategies, mental imagining, memorization, motivation, performance anxiety, injury prevention, collaboration among musicians, and creativity in music performance. Along with lectures on performers’ issues, students will engage in the study of their chosen repertoire and participate in discussion on related stylistic features and performance practice. All that cumulates into their final projects, interactive talk-performances where performers help audience members to listen, perform, create, and reflect in ways that heighten their musical perceptions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

* Understand and articulate mainstream ideas of concepts, techniques, methods, and experiences of music performers, pedagogues, psychologists, and researchers.
* Reflect in depth about critical similarities, differences, and intersections between their own and others’ perception in music performing and learning so as to demonstrate a deepening or transformation of original perspectives.
* Demonstrate competency in planning, preparing, and delivering effective interactive performance and evaluation strategies.
* Acquire and apply the necessary knowledge and skills needed to effectively deliver music performance.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics will include practice behaviour and retention, mental imaging, memorization concepts and strategies, motivation, performance anxiety, injury prevention, collaborative techniques and interaction in rehearsals, creativity in music performance, interacting and engaging with the audience, interaction and engaging with the audience, interactive talk-performance delivery.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Chinese Music: Selected Topics
courses.description: This course furthers the content of the foundation course in much greater depth. Selected examples of Chinese music will be covered with an emphasis on issues such as modernization and westernization in the 20th century. The course also highlights the challenges of Chinese music in the globalized world.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC2562 or permission by the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through this course, students will:

- Gain a more critical view of Chinese music, particularly on issues of modernity, traditions, identity in contemporary Chinese

music in the globalized world.

- Have a sound awareness of the ongoing challenges facing Chinese music such as development, survival and preservation

of cultural heritage and traditions.

- Further understand the realistic situation of “Chinese music” in the modern world.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Selected Topic in Music and Society
courses.description: Drawing upon current ethnomusicological theories and methods, the course explores selected issues in the social and cultural study of music such as nationalism in music, music and politics, music and religion.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through this course, students:

- Gain a board knowledge of theories and methods in ethnomusicology

- Develop an understanding of current issues in ethnomusicology

- Develop their interests in and further explore musics of non-Chinese and non-Western societies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Unit I: Approaching Ethnomusicology

Defining Ethnomusicology, Reviewing Ethnomusicology

Early Encounters: The Study of Non-Western Music in Colonial Times Sep 20 Descriptions and Transcriptions

Unit II: Comparative Musicology

Vergleichende Musikwissenschaft

Methods in Comparison: The Armchair vs. the Field

Canto- and Choreometrics

Unit III: The Early Era of Ethnomusicology

Ethnomusicological Challenges

The Anthropology of Music

Structuralist Paradigms

Unit IV: Remodeling Ethnomusicology

The “Music as Culture” Revolution: Sound Structure as Social Structure

Remodeling Ethnomusicology

Comparing Ethnomusicologies

Review, Presentations by Graduate Students in MUSC 6200

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Romanticism in Music
courses.description: This course explores the impact of the Romantic movement on music, beginning in the early years of the 19th century.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MUSC2813 and 2823 (for 3-year cohort) OR MUSC2872 and 2882 (for 4-year cohort) OR by consent of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students should have

• A much broadened knowledge of Western music history, especially that of the 19th century

• A good knowledge of the leading figures in the romantic movement

• New or enhanced skills in analyzing music and have developed the habit of thinking about the meaning that music conveys

• Gained experience in independent research and group work
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture topics to include

• General introduction to Romanticism: literature, painting and music

• The New German School – Wagner, Liszt, Berlioz and Bayreuth

• The War of the Romantics

• Chopin, Paris and the piano

• Virtuosity, Liszt, and Paganini

• Sentimentalism in music and literature

• Brahms and the symphony

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Approaches to Popular Music
courses.description: The course provides a grounding in approaches to thinking and writing about popular music critically, with some theoretical and musicological background in musical, historical, and cultural issues. It explores a variety of approaches, perspectives, and key issues in relation to featured songs, videos, and case studies. More broadly, it aims (i) to offer students a sense of the richness and diversity of approaches to popular music; (ii) to ask fundamental questions about the social location of popular music and its role in forming and responding to social practices; and (iii) to explore the interplay between popular music and broader cultural and historical phenomena.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): MUSC2872 and MUSC2882 or permission by the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
a) Knowledge and Understanding: engagement with and comprehension of a variety of cultural and artistic traditions in popular music studies; familiarity with modes of discourse operative in such studies; knowledge of relevant historical and cultural contexts

b) Intellectual skills: familiarity with current scholarship and modes of writing about popular music, from a variety of technical, critical and ideological angles; focused and where necessary analytical thinking about musical and performance styles, and the intellectual categories and tools which support such thinking; handling of concepts appropriate to the subject

c) Professional / practical skills: general self-organizational abilities; the ability to structure a subject area in terms of defining relevant topics and subtopics, and in identifying specific research tasks; competence in literature searches and in the handling and acknowledgement of sources, bibliographies, etc.; clear presentation of written essays and assignments

d) Transferable (key) skills: habits of reflective and critical thought; ability to organise information and construct arguments; clear and communicative use of language in both oral and written form; development of independent research and study skills
courses.course_syllabus: Topics are to be determined by the instructor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Effectiveness will be assessed through a mid-term questionnaire and a standard end-of-term course evaluation. The instructor will summarise the results of the evaluations and communicate the results to the students through appropriate means (verbally, by email, through Blackboard, etc.) in a timely manner.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: History of Film Music
courses.description: This course explores the changing role of music in film from the 1890s through to the present and the place of film in Western music history.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MUSC2872 and MUSC2882 OR by consent of the instructor
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through this course, students:

Gain a broad appreciation of the methods of film composers

Develop an understanding of how music and other sounds interact with visual images to communicate ideas

Expand their critical skills and develop the habit of questioning the meaning of what they see and hear
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1

Analyzing film music

Week 2

The silent Era

Week 3

Early sound film

Week 4

Soviet films and music

Week 5

France

Week 6

Britain

Week 7

Hollywood: the 1930s

Week 8

Hollywood: the 1940s

Week 9

Jazz and the 1950s

Week 10

Popular music and film

Week 11

Opera and film

Week 12

Science fiction

Weeks 13­‐14

New Hollywood: the 1970s and after

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music Pedagogy: Special Topic I
courses.description: A specialized study within music pedagogy. The focus of the course may be largely historical, theoretical, practical, or some combination of these. Regardless of the focus, each special topic will aim to expand the student’s conceptual understanding of teaching and learning music.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will have:
• An enhanced understanding of critical issues in music education
• Gained experience in thinking critically about the study of music
• Gained proficiency in expressing their views about music pedagogy both verbally and in writing and / or, have gained practical experience in an area of music pedagogy

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Early Music Ensemble VII
courses.description: This course provides students with opportunities to explore the vast world of early music through performance on replica period instruments. In consultation with the instructor, students select appropriate works from the repertoire, which ranges from antiquity through the early Classical era. Students prepare for an end-of-semester concert in weekly rehearsals that guide them through issues of technical proficiency, ensemble playing, stylistic accuracy, and creative expression.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Acquire skills in playing on and caring for period instruments

• Develop techniques of ensemble playing

• Develop sensitivity to issues of historical accuracy

• Formulate questions and answers about challenges in the early music repertoire

• Gain an appreciation of musical traditions that are historically distant
courses.course_syllabus:
• Correct care for and maintenance of delicate period instruments

• Sound production and issues of intonation, projection, and balance

• Historical background and cultural attributes of selected repertoire

• Possibilities for instrumentation and arrangement

• Articulation, phrasing, and rhythmic accuracy

• Challenges of notation, ornamentation, and improvisation

• Speaking and writing about early music through program notes and/or pre- and post-concert discussions

• End-of-term concert

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Research Methods in Music
courses.description: This course introduces students in the research stream to various tools and methods for undertaking music scholarship. Each student will select and explore a topic of interest during the term, culminating in an oral presentation and research paper. This course also includes practical units on professional development that are geared toward building a successful career in academia.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite(s): MUSC2262 and MUSC2882 (or permission by the instructor)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will develop knowledge of and skills in the following areas:

• critical reasoning with respect to music and its scholarly discourses

• standard research tools, library resources, and online databases

• proposing and developing substantial research projects

• formal writing standards (bibliographic style, citations, etc.)
courses.course_syllabus:
WK 1 – Course Introduction

WK 2 – Reading Critically I

WK 3 – Library Orientation and Online Research

WK 4 – Developing a Viable Thesis

WK 5 – One-on-One Meetings with the Instructor

WK 6 – Reading Critically II

WK 7 – Citations: Footnotes and Bibliographies

WK 8 – Reading Critically III

WK 9 – Mid-Term Oral Reports

WK 10 – Organizing Your Research

WK 11 – Reading Critically IV

WK 12 – Abstracts, Publishing, and Post-Graduate Study

WK 13 – Reading Critically V

WK 14 – Oral Presentations
courses.feedback_evaluation: Effectiveness will be assessed through a mid-term questionnaire and a standard end-of-term course evaluation. The instructor will summarise the results of the evaluations and communicate the results to the students through appropriate means (verbally, by email, through Blackboard, etc.) in a timely manner.
courses.required_readings: Detailed reading and listening lists specific to topical areas will be issued as appropriate.
courses.recommended_readings:
SAMPLE BIBLIOGRAPHY:

Botstein, Leon. “The Enigmas of Richard Strauss: A Revisionist View.” In Richard Strauss and His World, edited by Brian Gilliam, 3–28. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1992.

Cook, Nicholas. “We Are All (Ethno)Musicologists Now.” In The New (Ethno)Musicologies, edited by Henry Stobart, 48–70. Europea: Ethnomusicologies and Modernities 8. Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 2008.

Duckles, Vincent, et al. “Musicology.” In Grove Music Online. http:://www.oxfordmusic online.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/46710 (accessed September 1, 2011).

Kramer, Lawrence. “Musicology and Meaning.” The Musical Times 144, no. 1883 (Summer 2003): 6–12.

McClary, Susan. “Music and Sexuality: On the Steblin/Solomon Debate.” 19th-Century Music 17, no. 1 (Summer 1993): 83–88.

Pegg, Carole. “Ethnomusicology: I. Introduction.” In Grove Music Online. http:://www.oxfordmusic online.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/52178pg1 (accessed September 1, 2011).

Reynolds, Christopher. “Porgy and Bess, ‘An American Wozzeck’.” Journal of the Society for American Music 1, no. 1 (2007): 1–28.

“Richard Strauss.” The Musical Times 44, no. 719 (January 1903): 9–15.

Samson, Jim. “A View from Musicology.” In The New (Ethno)Musicologies, edited by Henry Stobart, 23–27. Europea: Ethnomusicologies and Modernities 8. Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 2008.

Solomon, Maynard. “Franz Schubert and the Peacocks of Benvenuto Cellini.” 19th-

Century Music 12, no. 3 (Spring 1989): 193–206.

Steblin, Rita. “A Peacock’s Tale: Schubert’s Sexuality Reconsidered.” 19th-Century

Music 17, no. 1 (Summer 1993): 5–33.

Subotnik, Rose Rosengard. “Shoddy Equipment for Living?: Deconstructing the Tin Pan Alley Song.” In Musicological Identities: Essays in Honor of Susan McClary, edited by Raymond Knapp, Steven Baur, and Jacqueline Warwick, 205–18. Aldershot, UK: Ashgate, 2008.

ADDITIONAL REFERENCES:

Crabtree, Phillip D. and Donald H. Foster. Sourcebook for Research in Music, Second Edition. Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2005

Sampsel, Laurie J. Music Research: A Handbook. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2008.

Wingell, Richard. Writing About Music: An Introductory Guide, Fourth Edition. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall, 2009.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Senior Pedagogy Project I
courses.description: This course forms the first half of a two-part capstone course in music pedagogy, in which students consolidate what they have learned in foundation courses. The capstone comprises a number of elements and may include observation of teaching practice, either in local schools or in private teaching studios; development of teaching materials; and writing an extended essay. In this course, in consultation with the course supervisor, students will devise a research plan and explore related pedagogical literature.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite(s): MUSC4243
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through this course, students will have:

• Learned how to prepare a research plan

• Enhanced their writing skills

• Deepened their knowledge of the related literature
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 Introduction and topic discussion

Week 2 Topics – and the MT collection

Week 3 Literature review

Week 4 (Sept 25: The Day following Mid-Autumn) Literature review

Week 5 (Oct 1: National Day) Literature review

Week 6 Literature review First continuous assessment grade

Week 7 (Oct 17: Chung Yeung Festival) Introduction writing

Week 8 Introduction writing

Week 9 Introduction writing

Week 10 Introduction writing

Week 11 Introduction writing

Week 12 Presentations

Week 13 Presentations

•Reflection of teacher

•Informal verbal feedback via private communication
courses.required_readings: Detailed reading and listening lists specific to topical areas will be issued as appropriate.
courses.recommended_readings:
Alexander, Robin J. Essays on Pedagogy. London and New York: Routledge, 2008.

Blanchard, Bonnie. Making Music and Enriching Lives:A Guide for All Music Teachers. Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2007.

Colwell, Richard J., ed. Basic Concepts in Music Education, II. Niwot, Colo.: University Press of Colorado,c1991.

Jorgensen, Estelle Ruth. The Art of Teaching Music. Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2008.

Kohut, Daniel L. Musical Performance: Learning Theory and Pedagogy. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice Hall, 1985.

McPherson, Gary E. The Child as Musician: A Handbook of Musical Development. Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 2006.

Swanwick, Keith. A Basis for Music Education. London: Routledge, 1992.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Senior Pedagogy Project II
courses.description: This course forms the second half of a two-part capstone course in music pedagogy, in which students consolidate what they have learned in foundation courses. The capstone comprises a number of elements and may include observation of teaching practice, either in local schools or in private teaching studios; development of teaching materials; and writing an extended essay. In this course, students will carry out the project that they have researched and planned in MUSC4513.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MUSC4513
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through this course, students will have:

• Gained experience completing a research project

• Enhanced their writing and presentation skills

• Deepened their knowledge of music pedagogy

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Senior Research Project I
courses.description: This course forms the first of a two-part course for capstone research projects in Music. It introduces students to the requisite scholarly and practical skills for conducting such projects.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To develop students’ ability in formulating and delimiting a research topic, producing a cogent argument, selecting an appropriate methodology, and presenting a coherent research proposal.
2. To train students in the construction of a thorough and pertinent bibliography, in the critique and synthesis of information collected through primary and/or secondary sources, and in the systematic integration of source materials with original thinking and argumentation.
3. To familiarize students with the styles and formats of academic writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
Through a series of weekly topics, the course will guide students in:

* choosing a research topic in an area of interest
* identifying and reviewing relevant secondary literature
* designing and applying appropriate methodologies
* formulating and fine-tuning research questions
* Identifying, selecting, and justifying the use of a range of primary and/or secondary sources as part of a project’s supporting evidence
* critical reading, reasoning, and argumentation
* academic citation formats
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Informal feedback via one-on-one communication
2. Early Feedback Collection system
3. Online course and teaching evaluation
courses.required_readings: The Chicago Manual of Style. Eighteenth Edition. University of Chicago Press, 2024.
courses.recommended_readings:
Williamon, Aaron, Jane Ginsborg, Rosie Perkins, and George Waddell. Performing Music Research: Methods in Music Education, Psychology, and Performance Science. Oxford University Press, 2021.

Miksza, Peter, Julia T. Shaw, Lauren Kapalka Richerme, Philip M. Hash, and Donald A.

Hodges. Music Education Research: An Introduction. Oxford University Press, 2023.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Senior Research Project II
courses.description: This course forms the second of a two-part course for capstone research projects in Music. Students will complete an extended independent research project under the supervision of a Music faculty member. The topic, contents, and other particulars of the project are to be determined in consultation with the Supervisor.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MUSC4613
courses.course_syllabus:
Possible research areas may include but are not limited to: one-on-one or group instrumental/vocal teaching; classroom music teaching in schools; aural or musicianship training; evaluation or development of teaching materials; questions and issues of promoting music to specific communities and groups; music therapy; repertoire-, composer-, or style-based analyses; structural, aesthetic, or critical theory; historical, sociocultural, anthropological, philosophical, or other thematic and contextual studies of musical practices; archival research; ethnographic fieldwork on specific communities or groups; or interdisciplinary scholarship, applications, and debates.

The final submission may take one of several forms as specified in the Capstone Handbook.
