courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Traditional Musical Culture in China
courses.description: Covering significant issues and topics in the study of Chinese music history, this course focuses on traditional Chinese music and its relevance to modern society. It aims to expose students to both Chinese and international scholarship by means of an up-to-date discussion of the historiography of Chinese music.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Cover significant issues and topics in traditional Chinese musical culture
• Reinforce and expand critical insight from a wide spectrum of perspectives
• Demonstrate a postgraduate level of competence in critical judgments about traditional Chinese music
courses.course_syllabus:
大綱 内容
課程簡介及導論 中國音樂的基本概念、歷史發展及起源 中國樂器 中國樂器分類法、曾侯乙墓樂器
中國音樂記譜法 中國音樂記譜法及其意義 音樂與文字 介紹不同朝代的音樂文學
戲曲 介紹崑劇、京劇、上海越劇和粤劇等劇種 從制禮作樂到禮崩樂壞 介紹重要的音樂機構及音樂思想
courses.feedback_evaluation: 此課程共有兩次課程評估，分别安排在學期中段及結束之前。同學在學習上有任何問題，請透過電郵與教師聯絡，有需要亦可安排會面。

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Musical Culture in Contemporary China
courses.description: Focusing on the modernization, westernization and globalization faced by the Chinese since the early 20th century, this course deals with the survival, positioning and cultural environment of Chinese music. Based on recent scholarly discourse in China and the West, the course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to the study of contemporary Chinese music.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Formulate a critical overview of the musical development in China from the late 19th century to the present
• Identify new issues and make informed judgments about new types of music by Chinese composers appearing in Mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and overseas
• Apply knowledge and skills in professional activities such as research and music performance
• Develop creative and original responses to problems and issues found in the development of music in modern China.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. ) TheEstablishmentofMusic EducationinChinainthelate19thCentury.

2. ) TheDevelopmentofVocalMusicfrom1900(artsongs,patrioticsongs,etc.)

3. ) TheDevelopmentofMusicwrittenforWesternInstruments.

i) for solo instrument with or without accompaniment

ii) for chamber ensemble

iii) for orchestra

4. ) The Evolution of the Chinese Orchestra: HK, Taiwan, Mainland China and Singapore.

5. ) Music Drama, Opera, Revolutionary Opera and Musical.

6. ) Music written by Hong Kong, Taiwan and Overseas Chinese Composers.

7. ) The Mixing of Western and Chinese Instruments.

8. ) Popular Music in the Chinese Communities.
courses.feedback_evaluation: mid-term and end-term course evaluation
courses.required_readings: Readings relevant to the topic discussed will be recommended during the course.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music and Popular Culture in Hong Kong
courses.description: Music and culture are the points of departure. Popular song and film of Hong Kong are studied in relationship to the unique political, historical and cultural position of Hong Kong. The issue of identity will be further explored from the perspectives of cultural studies, ethnomusicology and musicology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Develop and reinforce critical insight from a wide spectrum of perspectives
• Develop a postgraduate level of competence in critical thinking about various kinds of popular culture and the multifarious meanings behind them
courses.course_syllabus: The course focuses on music and the "popular" culture of Hong Kong. It aims to develop students' critical insight from a wide spectrum of perspectives. Taking a multi-disciplinary approach, the course incorporates concepts from literatury, history, anthropology, ethnomusicology, cultural studies, performance studies, and cultural politics to the study of music. In order to cultivate students' sensitivity in their perception of music, be it popular, classical or traditional, the course is designed to provide a solid foundation in critical perspective rather than covering Hong Kong popular culture exhaustively. Examples covered are inevitably f'historical." Students are encouraged to identify update examples in their presentations and papers. Watching movies and reading books are absolutely necessary. Going to cinema, concerts and "performances" of various kinds of art are highly recommended.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mid-term and end-term course evaluation.
courses.required_readings: All refer to the recommeded readings

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music in Film
courses.description: This course examines the role of music in film. It enables students with no training in music or media studies to better appreciate the art of film music. Through lectures and assignments that comprise viewing, reading, and listening, students gain skills to critically evaluate what they see and hear in feature films, animated films, music videos, and advertisements.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Expand knowledge of film and gain a broad appreciation of the methods of film composers
• Develop an understanding of how music and other sounds interact with visual images to communicate ideas
• Enhance critical skills and develop the habit of questioning the meaning of what is seen and heard on screen
courses.course_syllabus:
* Course structure and topics covered*

In the first two weeks of the term, lectures will focus on tenninology and theory. After this, lectures will explore different genres, such as science fiction, and the work of specific directors and composers. For each topic, there are assigned readings and a short written assignment that requires critical engagement with the subject.

All required material will be available on the course website on Blackboard (https://elearn.cuhk.edu.hk).

Students are advised to download a copy of the week's presentation (pdf) before class Gt may not be available until

just a few hours before class). Selected clips (Quicktime files) will be available after each lesson.

The readings are drawn from numerous sources and are accessible while treating the subject seriously and in

considerable depth. Supplemental readings may also be made available on Blockboard.
courses.feedback_evaluation: mid-term and end-term course evaluation.
courses.required_readings: Refer to the recommended readings

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music-Making in Global Contexts
courses.description: This course provides an in depth study of how music is created and performed in various selected music cultures across the globe, with particular emphasis placed on how aesthetic systems of all types (classical, folk, popular, etc.) shape and are shaped by socio-cultural factors and mechanisms, such as place, identity, social structure, globalization, and social change.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
\* Acquire deeper understandings of how music is created, produced, transmitted,

and consumed in selected countries and culture regions from around the world

\* Be able to recognize, interpret, and evaluate aesthetic and stylistic features

of selected musical systems

\* Gain critical insight into socio-cultural and contextual concerns related to

music making, such as environment/place, identity, social structure, globalization, and

social/musical change

\* Sharpen critical listening, reading, and thinking skills
courses.course_syllabus:
• Methodologies of research and analysis

• Theories and models of music and society

• Aural analysis

• Aesthetics of selected musical systems and forms

• Processes of production, dissemination, and consumption

• Critical perspectives on place, representation, and cultural and national identity

• Concepts of tradition and authenticity

• Issues of globalization and social change
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• End Class Feedback (every lecture)

• Course Evaluation Questionnaire (mid-term)

• Course Evaluation Questionnaire (end-term)

• External Examiner Report; Teacher Reflection

• Tenzer, Michael and John Roeder, eds. Analytical and Cross-Cultural Studies in World Music. Oxford: Oxford University

Press, 2011.

• Titon, Jedd Todd, ed. Worlds of Music: An Introduction to the Music of the World’s Peoples. Belmont, CA: Schirmer

Cengage Learning, 2009.

The topic can be of Western or non-Western music, subject to the availability of the teacher. A paper (or, in the case of practical subjects, a portfolio or a musical presentation) should be delivered at the end of the course.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music Management and Promotion
courses.description: The aim of the course is to enable students to learn the theoretical concepts of music management and promotion as well as to examine how these are applied in various music industries in Hong Kong. Students will thus acquire a better understanding of the context and the dissemination of music in the Hong Kong community. Their perspectives on music promotion and ability to analyze critical issues relating to music and society will be enhanced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Gain an overview of the fundamental concepts and skills in the management and promotion of music
• Learn and benefit from experienced and successful practitioners in the field in the application of key concepts and skills in
real life situations
courses.course_syllabus:
This course aims to examine the development of music in Hong Kong from the perspectives of management, promotion and policy. Students will learn key concepts relating to the management and promotion of music /arts activities as well as music organizations. Topics such as planning, programming,marketing,audience development, financial management, human resources management, fundraising will be discussed. Students will have the chance to apply some of these concepts in their assignments.

Whilst the main theories and concepts will be delivered by the Instructor, a number of guest speakers from different spheres of the music industry will share real life-cases as well as their insights on music management and promotion.
courses.feedback_evaluation: A number of short on li ne surveys will be conducted during the cou rse to enhance students' learning through active engagement. These surveys will also collect students' feed back on teaching and learning. Students are encouraged to share their views and concerns with the professor in person or via e-mail.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Tonal Skills
courses.description: The course is designed as a conceptual and practical study of the harmonic materials of music of the common practice period, with equal emphasis on developing students’ written and aural skills as well as analytical and creative abilities. It prepares students for more advanced composing and arranging courses with in-depth study of the harmonic techniques used by western composers the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, placing special emphasis on developing the students’ ability to analyze and write in various important styles concerned.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Good knowledge and mastery of the harmonic techniques used by composers in the classical and romantic periods.
* Assured attentiveness to the harmonic conventions of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, through applications based on common-practice models.
* Sound understanding of important compositional concepts related to freedom and boundaries, simplicity and complexity, tension and relaxation, unity and contrasts, etc., typical of the styles concerned.
* Successful application of scoring conventions in the expression and communication of musical ideas.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Consonance vs. dissonance
* Non-harmonic tones (as essential ingredients of melodic / rhythmic expansion)
* Principles of part writing
* Chorale setting in the style of J. S. Bach
* Chorale transformation: scoring for other texture types
* Construction and realization of a musical idea
* Linear considerations and distribution of voices
* Developing accompaniment styles
* Diatonic seventh chords in sequence and other expanded usage
* Extended usage of chromaticism
* Techniques of modulations and variations
* Melodic construction and linear expansion
* Harmonic practice of the classical masters
* Keyboard works and string quartets of the classical period
* Harmonic practice of the romantic masters
* German lieder, French choral works, and Wagnerian chromaticism
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mid-term and end-term course evaluation.
courses.required_readings: Course pack (containing all lecture notes, illustration examples and reading materials) prepared by course instructor.
courses.recommended_readings:
Benjamin / Horvit / Nelson:

Techniques and Materials of Tonal Music

Aldwell / Schachter:

Harmony and Voice Leading

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Practical Composing and Arranging
courses.description: The course is designed as a practical guide, leading the arranger (as a composer) through the entire process of creative imagination to the completion of an arrangement and the preparation of a score. Students are introduced to the concepts of melodic construction, harmonic expansion, rhythmic elaboration, and techniques of modulation and variation. They will be given assignments to score for various texture types, compose introductions, transitions and codas, develop accompaniment styles, and to plan the form of an arrangement. Emphasis will be given to practical scoring for specifi c groups, such as for church and school choir, wind band and chamber orchestra. Considerations in popular music will also be discussed. Prerequisite: attained at least ABRSM Grade 8 (or equivalent) in theory.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Acquire mastery of the musical language being employed for use
• Develop the ability to treat and develop ideas in musically interesting ways
• Develop consistency in writing in the styles concerned
• Gain awareness of writing idiomatically for musical instruments and/or the human voice
• Acquire the ability to communicate effectively through preparation of a musical score
courses.course_syllabus: The course is designed as a practical guide, leading the composer/arranger through the process of creative imagination to the completion of an original composition/ arrangement and the preparation of a decent score. Students are introduced with concepts of melodic construction, harmonic expansion, rhythmic elaborations, and techniques of modulations and variations. They will be given an experience to score for various texture types, compose introductions, transitions and codas, develop accompaniment styles, and to plan the form of an arrangement. Emphasis will be given to practical scoring under specific settings, such as for the church and the school choir, or for ensembles of limited 'resources. Considerations in pop music will also play an important part along the line.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Music Information Technology
courses.description: This course introduces the usage and the application of the most up-to-date computer, audio engineering and electronic technology. Emphasis will be placed on both the theory and practicalities of computer music software and its application in the classroom and church. Students need to do studio work.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Gain advanced knowledge of music technology and the vocabulary used in the field
• Gain advanced knowledge and concepts of sound theory
• Acquire skills of how to process and play back musical scores on the computer
• Apply the techniques studied to electronic orchestration and explore their utility in various contexts such as classrooms or
church services
• Apply technology more generally to assist in learning and working
courses.course_syllabus:
The course is divided into various units, some units take longer than one lecture and some take less.

1. Advanced Sound Theory

1. 1 Nature of sound and vibration

1. 2 Knowledge and application of audio equipment

2. Advanced Musical Instrument Digital Interface (MIDI)

2. 1 Advanced MIDI application

2. 2 MIDI machine control

2. 3 MIDI show control

3. Recording

3. 1 Theory of Analog and digital recording

3. 2 Theory of different type of microphone

3. 3 Technique of field recording

3. 4 Microphone placement

3. 5 Music Recording

4. Computer Scoring and Sequencing

4. 1 Advanced technique of the Notation software (Case study: Finale)

4. 2 Advanced technique of the Sequencing software (Case study: Digital

Performer)

5. Sound Design and signal Processing

5. 1 Sound Design for Stage performance (Case study: QLab)

5. 2 Harddisk Recording and Digital Signal Processing (Case study: ProTools)

6. Acoustic Design and Acoustic improvement

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Writing Music for the Church
courses.description: The course is an extension of MUS8009. Designed in the form of a workshop, students are guided through the process of planning and developing a musical work along with the actual making of the music in class. Emphasis will be given to developing skills typically required for the church musician, including those of keyboard improvisation, practical scoring for ensembles of limited resource, musical setting for congregational hymns, and the writing of descant, varied accompaniment, worship chorus and anthem, etc. (Prerequisite: attained at least ABRSM Grade 8 Theory or equivalent. Students who have taken MUS8009 will be given priority.)
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Master skills of hymn improvisation and writing descants
• Learn to plan and effect modulations
• Develop materials for the introduction, transition, and concluding sessions
• Gain experience in setting melody to a Chinese text
• Learn how to compose varied accompaniment, especially for the organ
• Write worship choruses and produce an anthem

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Entrepreneurship and New Vision in Music
courses.description: This course aims to broaden students’ outlook on how music can connect with and add value to contemporary society. It introduces students to basic concepts of entrepreneurship and major toolkits used by entrepreneurs in planning their business ventures. It also examines different local and overseas cases which demonstrate new vision in music, both of commercial nature and for social good.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Understand the qualities and mindset of entrepreneurs, and how these attributes can be useful for personal development
* Enhance capacity to identify opportunities in the music /arts /cultural ecology and create value for stakeholders
* Acquire ability to make use of planning toolkits in strategic planning, positioning, and the design of business model, both at organizational and personal levels
* Identify and learn from local and overseas cases demonstrating innovations in music, including new beneficiaries, new distribution channels, new social values, new formats and new means of participation /engagement.
courses.course_syllabus:
In recent years technological advances, concerns on social equity and cross-disciplinary explorations have led to new and exciting developments in music and the arts. The value of music in the society and its mode of engagement with audiences are being re-defined by these new developments. These innovations in the music industry are driven by entrepreneurs who are both visionaries and realist at the same time. This course aims to equip students with basic concepts of entrepreneurship and major toolkits used by entrepreneurs in planning and executing their business ventures. Students will examine cases demonstrating new vision in different aspects, from those adding commercial or artistic value, to those for social good.

A number of music entrepreneurs will be invited to share real-life cases as well as their insights on entrepreneurship. Students are required to apply what they learned through designing a new entity.
courses.feedback_evaluation:

* Informal feedback from students, via private communication with instructor
* Internal course review

courses.title: Frontiers in Music Theory
courses.description: Course Objective: This is a course 1. For musicians who love to brush up on their analytical techniques for teaching, performance and understanding of music. 2. For musicians who want to have a birds-eye view on the new development of music theory in the last 50 years. 3. For music educators who want to be successful in "Aural Training"and the teaching of theory. Contents: This 12-week term course is designed to study the formal structures of music and to familiarize music students with some of the most useful analytical tools. Some of the topics may include the thematic process of music; post Schenkerian theory; post-tonal understanding of music; and how listen to music structurally.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Western Opera & Vocal Literature
courses.description: A survey of Western opera and related vocal literature from Baroque to the present. Emphasis on exploring historical, stylistic, and aesthetic aspects of representative works and their leading composers through the perspectives of composer, performer, and audience. The classes will explore various opera scenes, songs and other vocal repertoire and their associated performance practice through historical and analytical reading, discussion and analysis of recorded performances, score reading, and source study. Along with weekly lectures, students participate in in-class discussions, complete class exercises, and work towards their final project presentations combining scholarly work and practical work.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Reinforce and expand awareness of significant operatic and other vocal genres, performance practices, and musical conventions of the historical periods studied
• Demonstrate a postgraduate level of competence in critical judgments about Western vocal music
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will provide a history of Western opera, starting from its origin, leading into the twentieth centuries; as well as looking into the development of chamber and solo vocal literature. Opera has been for four hundred years one of the world's most extraordinary and enthralling artistic mediums, representing human passions with astonishing power and drama. The course will introduce various social, political, and literary contexts of operas and related vocal literature, examine their national traditions, and encounter the debates and polemics that have accompanied the development of the art forms throughout its history. Consideration will also be given to issues of performance past and present. Works by the greatest composers are included, from Monteverdi, Bach, Mozart, Schumann, Rossini, Verdi, and Wagner, to Puccini, Debussy, Berg, and Shostakovich. Students will gain detailed knowledge of and skills in the following areas:

* major composers and core repertoire of Western opera and vocal music
* relationships between operatic styles and their historical contexts
* presentation of new material as preparation for future teaching
* independent study as the foundation of research in the field of musicology
* a critical essay and presentation on a selected topic serve as the final project
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mid-term and end-term course evaluation.

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Western Instrumental Literature
courses.description: This course aims to familiarize students with major Solo, Chamber and Orchestral instrumental works from the 18th century to the contemporary period. Through regular listening and reading assignments, students will be able to explore the stylistic and analytical issues surrounding the genres of Western instrumental music, with emphasis on the relationships between musical form and genre, between genre and style, and how Western art music evolves through time.

By exploring the stylistic and analytical issues surrounding major genres of Western instrumental music, such as the Symphony, the String quartet, and the Sonata, topics on style and interpretation are brought into discussion.

• Learn how to conduct music with healthy and relaxed body gestures

• Develop critical self-evaluation of conducting a rehearsal or a concert

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Topics in Musicology I
courses.description: Specialized historical or genre studies exploring aspects of music creation, analysis, or performance of Western music. A substantial oral presentation and research paper will be required during the term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD/MPhil/DMus/MMus in Music
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will have:
a) acquired detailed knowledge of a specialized musicological subject (e.g. period, genre, or topic-based).
b) gained a deep understanding of the relationship between the topic specified and its socio-historical context
c) developed skills at presenting material as part of his or her professional training
d) developed critical thinking and independent study skills as foundations of research in the field of musicology
